{"comments": {"id": 27547, "count": 40, "talk_id": 4669}, "threadId": 27547, "requested_language_english_name": "English", "current_talk": "4669", "description": "We all know that when we make decisions in groups, they don't always go right -- and sometimes they go very wrong. How can groups make good decisions? With his colleague Dan Ariely, neuroscientist Mariano Sigman has been inquiring into how we interact to reach decisions by performing experiments with live crowds around the world. In this fun, fact-filled explainer, he shares some intriguing results -- as well as some implications for how it might impact our political system. In a time when people seem to be more polarized than ever, Sigman says, better understanding how groups interact and reach conclusions might spark interesting new ways to construct a healthier democracy.", "event": "TED Studio", "language": "en", "language_swap": false, "name": "Mariano Sigman and Dan Ariely: How can groups make good decisions?", "slug": "mariano_sigman_and_dan_ariely_how_can_groups_make_good_decisions", "series_slug": null, "speakers": [{"id": "332", "slug": "dan_ariely", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Dan", "lastname": "Ariely", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Behavioral economist", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/1a36ab42198d58992285a8570a4fb7e75e21d10e_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "If you want to know why you always buy a bigger television than you intended, or why you think it's perfectly fine to spend a few dollars on a cup of coffee at Starbucks, or why people feel better after taking a 50-cent aspirin but continue to complain of a throbbing skull when they're told the pill they took just cost one penny, Ariely has the answer.", "whotheyare": "The dismal science of economics is not as firmly grounded in actual behavior as was once supposed. In "Predictably Irrational," Dan Ariely told us why.", "whylisten": "

Dan Ariely is a professor of psychology and behavioral economics at Duke University and a founding member of the Center for Advanced Hindsight. He is the author of the bestsellers Predictably Irrational, The Upside of Irrationality, and The Honest Truth About Dishonesty -- as well as the TED Book Payoff: The Hidden Logic that Shapes Our Motivations.

Through his research and his (often amusing and unorthodox) experiments, he questions the forces that influence human behavior and the irrational ways in which we often all behave.

"}, {"id": "2376", "slug": "mariano_sigman", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Mariano", "lastname": "Sigman", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Neuroscientist", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/21a1b23e3429e7bfce1efb26838458c90717d53b_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "Sigman provides vivid depictions of foundational behavioral psychology experiments...[His] book's exhaustive survey of experiments is, overall, enlightening, and Sigman's clear passion for neuroscience makes it easy to browse.", "whotheyare": "In his provocative, mind-bending book "The Secret Life of the Mind," neuroscientist Mariano Sigman reveals his life’s work exploring the inner workings of the human brain.", "whylisten": "

Mariano Sigman, a physicist by training, is a leading figure in the cognitive neuroscience of learning and decision making. Sigman was awarded a Human Frontiers Career Development Award, the National Prize of Physics, the Young Investigator Prize of "College de France," the IBM Scalable Data Analytics Award and is a scholar of the James S. McDonnell Foundation. In 2016 he was made a Laureate of the Pontifical Academy of Sciences.

In The Secret Life of the Mind, Sigman's ambition is to explain the mind so that we can understand ourselves and others more deeply. He shows how we form ideas during our first days of life, how we give shape to our fundamental decisions, how we dream and imagine, why we feel certain emotions, how the brain transforms and how who we are changes with it. Spanning biology, physics, mathematics, psychology, anthropology, linguistics, philosophy and medicine, as well as gastronomy, magic, music, chess, literature and art, The Secret Life of the Mind revolutionizes how neuroscience serves us in our lives, revealing how the infinity of neurons inside our brains manufacture how we perceive, reason, feel, dream and communicate.

"}], "url": "https://www.ted.com/talks/mariano_sigman_and_dan_ariely_how_can_groups_make_good_decisions", "viewed_count": 1450007, "talks": [{"recommendations": {"status": "approved", "headline": "Mariano Sigman recommends", "blurb": "Extra resources curated by Mariano Sigman", "start_at": null, "end_at": null, "published": true, "eyebrow": "", "type": "recommendation", "rec_lists": [{"title": "Books", "description": "", "rec_items": [{"label": "READ_Book", "headline": "*The Secret Life of the Mind*", "blurb": "", "note": "Mariano Sigman William Collins, 2017", "link_url": "https://www.amazon.com/Secret-Life- Mind-Thinks- Decides/dp/0316549622/ref=as_li_tf_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=0520271440&linkCode=as2&tag=teco06-20", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}, {"label": "READ_Book", "headline": "*Democracy and Deliberation: New Directions for Democratic Reform*", "blurb": "This book proposes a new kind of democracy for the modern era, one that not only gives citizens more power but also allows them more opportunities to exercise this power thoughtfully. James S. Fishkin here suggests an innovative solution to the problem of inadequate deliberation, in particular within our presidential nomination system. His reform involves a well-publicized national caucus in which a representative sample of American citizens would interact directly with presidential contenders in order to reflect and vote on the issues and candidates.", "note": "James Fishkin Yale University Press, 1993", "link_url": "https://www.amazon.com/Democracy-Deliberation-Directions-Democratic-Reform/dp/0300051638/ref=as_li_tf_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=0520271440&linkCode=as2&tag=teco06-20", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}, {"label": "READ_Book", "headline": "*Robot Dreams (Remembering Tomorrow)*", "blurb": "This book is recommended especially for the short story “Franchise” in which Asimov inquiries about our capacity to to sample a small number of votes to predict a total election outcome, and takes this idea to the extreme, reflecting on voting and deliberation.", "note": "Isaac Asimov Ace, 1990", "link_url": "https://www.amazon.com/Robot-Dreams-Remembering-Tomorrow-Asimov/dp/0441731546/ref=as_li_tf_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=0520271440&linkCode=as2&tag=teco06-20", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}, {"label": "READ_Book", "headline": "*Extraordinary Popular Delusions and The Madness of Crowds*", "blurb": "A classic that still reflects the most relevant principles on why collective decisions may go wrong, and lead to misconception, and delusion. Written more than 150 years ago it seems that it is never been as relevant as in these days. ", "note": "Charles Macka Dover Publications, 2003", "link_url": "https://www.amazon.com/Extraordinary-Popular-Delusions-Charles-Mackay/dp/0486432238/ref=as_li_tf_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=9325&creativeASIN=0520271440&linkCode=as2&tag=teco06-20", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}]}, {"title": "Papers", "description": "", "rec_items": [{"label": "READ_Article", "headline": ""Aggregated knowledge from a small number of debates outperforms the wisdom of large crowds"", "blurb": "Aggregated knowledge from a small number of debates outperforms the wisdom of large crowds. This preprint (accepted in principle in the journal Nature Human Behavior) presents the experiment described in the first part of the talk, providing experimental demonstrations that small debates lead to much more accurate collective judgments. ", "note": "Joaquin Navajas, Tamara Niella, Gerry Garbulsky, Bahador Bahrami and Mariano Sigman", "link_url": "https://arxiv.org/ftp/arxiv/papers/1703/1703.00045.pdf", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}, {"label": "READ_Article", "headline": ""How social influence can undermine the wisdom of crowd effect"", "blurb": "This paper shows how (and why) social influence can undermine the wisdom of the crowds.", "note": "Jan Lorenza, Heiko Rauhutb, Frank Schweitzera and Dirk Helbing *PNAS*, 2010", "link_url": "http://www.pnas.org/content/108/22/9020.abstract", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}, {"label": "READ_Article", "headline": ""Improving Collective Estimations Using Resistance to Social Influence"", "blurb": "", "note": "Gabriel Madirolas and Gonzalo G. de Polavieja *PLOS*, 2015", "link_url": "http://journals.plos.org/ploscompbiol/article?id=10.1371/journal.pcbi.1004594", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}]}, {"title": "Talks", "description": "", "rec_items": [{"label": "WATCH", "headline": "TEDxperiments at TEDxRíodelaPlata 2016", "blurb": "In 2016, TEDxperiments at TEDxRíodelaplata was performed by [El Gato y la Caja](https://elgatoylacaja.com.ar/). El Gato y La Caja (The Cat and The Box) is a communication, research and design collective whose goal is to spread the scientific way of seeing the world and the importance of making evidence-informed decisions. The collective conducts large-scale experiments in social psychology.", "note": "YouTube", "link_url": "https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XcUlIkyGZyg", "position": null, "is_pdf": false, "eyebrow": ""}, {"label": "WATCH", "headline": "TEDxperiments at TEDxRíodelaPlata 2015", "blurb": "The TEDxRíodelaPlata event where we performed [this experiment](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qvcVzr2x8Jg) to ask how debates may improve collective wisdom. told the pill they took just cost one penny, Ariely has the answer.", "whotheyare": "The dismal science of economics is not as firmly grounded in actual behavior as was once supposed. In "Predictably Irrational," Dan Ariely told us why.", "whylisten": "

Dan Ariely is a professor of psychology and behavioral economics at Duke University and a founding member of the Center for Advanced Hindsight. He is the author of the bestsellers Predictably Irrational, The Upside of Irrationality, and The Honest Truth About Dishonesty -- as well as the TED Book Payoff: The Hidden Logic that Shapes Our Motivations.

Through his research and his (often amusing and unorthodox) experiments, he questions the forces that influence human behavior and the irrational ways in which we often all behave.

"}, {"id": "2376", "slug": "mariano_sigman", "is_published": true, "firstname": "Mariano", "lastname": "Sigman", "middleinitial": "", "title": "", "description": "Neuroscientist", "photo_url": "https://pe.tedcdn.com/images/ted/21a1b23e3429e7bfce1efb26838458c90717d53b_254x191.jpg", "whatotherssay": "Sigman provides vivid depictions of foundational behavioral psychology experiments...[His] book's exhaustive survey of experiments is, overall, enlightening, and Sigman's clear passion for neuroscience makes it easy to browse.", "whotheyare": "In his provocative, mind-bending book "The Secret Life of the Mind," neuroscientist Mariano Sigman reveals his life’s work exploring the inner workings of the human brain.", "whylisten": "

Mariano Sigman, a physicist by training, is a leading figure in the cognitive neuroscience of learning and decision making. Sigman was awarded a Human Frontiers Career Development Award, the National Prize of Physics, the Young Investigator Prize of "College de France," the IBM Scalable Data Analytics Award and is a scholar of the James S. McDonnell Foundation. In 2016 he was made a Laureate of the Pontifical Academy of Sciences.

In The Secret Life of the Mind, Sigman's ambition is to explain the mind so that we can understand ourselves and others more deeply. He shows how we form ideas during our first days of life, how we give shape to our fundamental decisions, how we dream and imagine, why we feel certain emotions, how the brain transforms and how who we are changes with it. Spanning biology, physics, mathematics, psychology, anthropology, linguistics, philosophy and medicine, as well as gastronomy, magic, music, chess, literature and art, The Secret Life of the Mind revolutionizes how neuroscience serves us in our lives, revealing how the infinity of neurons inside our brains manufacture how we perceive, reason, feel, dream and communicate.

"}], "speaker_name": "Mariano Sigman and Dan Ariely", "tags": ["choice", "collaboration", "community", "communication", "Debate", "data", "democracy", "science", "decision-making", "society", "social change", "psychology"], "title": "How can groups make good decisions?", "video_type": {"id": "6", "name": "Original Content"}, "viewed_count": 1450007}]}
